reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state, I have to recommend this game!

Couple of points at the end explain the overall rating.

Pros:

- Cute Artstyle
- AI 90% of the time is perfect
- Can build almost anything you want to
- Hard mode actually adds survival challenge to this otherwise peaceful town builder
- Constantly being developed/improved
- Indepth profession system with RPG style progression
- Happy to just watch my villagers do their thing!

Cons:

- AI doesn't work 10% of the time
- Buildings you designate to build sometime never get finished (Look at bottom of post)
- Combat AI is dodgey. I have to tell them to Defend a location, to get them to attack monsters

Notes:

The reason it is a yes is solely based upon the ability to use the Command Console (CTRL + SHIFT + C).

This allows you to Instantly Build buildings your villagers refuse to build, and you can destroy buildings already created.
Without these two commands (IB & Destroy), I would have raged quit this game years ago.

I'd say 50% of custom buildings never get finished if they are semi-complicated. Sometimes the villagers, when you tell them to place items, never actually place it and you're stuck with the ghost icon.

But with 'Destroy', you get rid of it, and with 'IB' you can sort the building issues out!
You even have a Teleport command if your villagers get stuck!

Hopefully they will remove the need for the console, but until then I have to give this a 8/10 IF you use the Console.

Without the Console, it'd only be a 5/10.

EDIT: I'm rewriting a review because I love this game a lot and want people to really understand whats going on.

This game has so much potential. The devs really care and want it to be a good game.
It's playable in the current state but at the same time it isn't.
You will face several gamebreaking bugs during your play.
I frequently try to play this game and see how it's going.
HUD breaks, hearthlings don't do what you ask.
Devs post weekly (most of the time on tuesday) about the upcomming updates, and i really like how much they communicate with the backers/supporters (i backed this game on kickstarter awhile back)

overall I believe it would be better to add this to your wishlist/watch list and check back every once and awhile.
If you buy it now you might find a few bugs and get frustrated.

I'll edit this more in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love it!
Though it still is in  alpha  and theres yet much missing and to be added, the whole concept and gameplay is good.
Quite good. I love RTS games and iv allways wanted/missed a city building game with a medeival/fantasy theme and now here it is. It gave me a realy good first impression; artstyle of the game is wonderfull, the mechanics for now is also nice though it still needs some work, most features are great. I have much hope and belief that this game will become a great.

Some important notes:

- Graphics/artstyle is fine and refreshing, it resembles minecraft obviously but much more clean and polished so i wouldnt be worrying about the graphical look if you're that type of guy. Artstyle, by the look of the concept art there is a lot more cool stuff to come and im eager to test out the upcoming updates.

- Mechanics in the game are okay: Not bad or to unique which fits perfectly, it may be a bit tricky to learn the basics in the game without a tutorial or guidline in-game but its workable.
I love the ability to  customize the buildings and housings entirely from scratch , this was a suckerpunch for me and sold me. You can then later on decide what the building should be used for and as (example blacksmith, barracks, tavern etc.. etc). You can also customize the interior as in rugs, curtains, style of furniture and so on.
I find it amusing that this is a RTS with such neat customization features, it realy makes it fun for people who appriciate city building games down to the tiniest details.

Classes of the workers so far is well made, cant complain besides the lack of a ranged/archer class but that will be added later and many more other classes as well have they noted.

- Lore/Story, not much to say about that now in the Alpha but after what iv read it looks promising for what is to come. There are some quests with the goblins which are pretty neat but there isnt much else to say about that.

-Upcoming features; Multiplayer, coop will be fun i believe. Im looking more forward to the concept of coop in a city building game, im interested to see if they will make it so players can build one big city together and manage it as well, if so that would be awesome.


The negative about the game?

Its an alpha, bugs and glitches are to be expected. Only major flaw i find in the current alpha is that the game will lag/crash when you pass the villager/worker limit of 25 +. Besides that i cant find much flaw in it knowing a lot more concent will be added and fixed.



I strongly recommend the game 8/10, its a neat mix of RTS and RPG . Its like a small mix of Warcraft 3, Banished, Age of Mythology and Age of Empires.   40 hours in  and its just a alpha! Realy entertaining so far, and i look forward to what the developers will do with the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really do love the concept of this game.  The game has settlers left in the wilds to fend for themselves.  They slowly start to learn the basics to create their own city and a home for themeslves.

At this point, though, the game is not ready.  The bugs are hard to get over and the game has not been updated to handle 'end of game' content or what happens when you level.  I build a place for everyone to sleep, to eat and then I'm pretty much done.  I have everyone collect resources, but really this only happens sometimes.  My blacksmith or Mason level up to create new things for my settlement, but I'm unable to impliment them, I don't see a reason to use them, and I can't make my own due to glitches.

Now I don't want you to stray from the basic game.  Despite this all, as I frist stated, the game is headed in the right direction and I hope it continues that way.  If the developer can pull this all together I think we'll have a huge hit on our hands a game I won't be able to stop playing.

I do think the game is worth a try!  Watch out for the goblins!

This game is definitely worth your money, it's a great combination of RPG and City building and has many planned features that are currently being added or will be added eventually. Another great thing this game has is its active developers, who have consistently provided updates on the games progress and listened to the communities feedback, so you always know what's going down and will never leave the community out of loop wondering where the games is *Cough* Cube World *Cough*. If you want to see for yourself simply go to stonehearth.net and visit the Dev Blog.

So if you're into city builders, RPG's and active developers this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first bought this game I was upset at all of the constant game breaking bugs and instability. Constant content updates but no bug updates. (Early access rules clearly state the game must be playable through all stages of development) but as time went on the game's bugs were slowly pushed back, some weren't completely removed. Of course this is all expected of a early access game, however it was pretty bad.

Every now and then I come back to stonehearth and see the amazing improvements they have made. Since the game is early access it has its limitations, one of the major ones was the idle bug" which caused all of the villagers to permanently cease any and all activity and the save would be permanently broken. However they added a cap of 24 villagers now and optimized the game. So now we are limited to just 24 villagers.


All in all I love the game and love the spirit of stonehearth 8/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has the potential to become something great, but i feel the game is a little disorganized in gameplay.  Theres some micromanagement needed to produce goods, and I feel the hearthlings needs better AI to collect reasources and items that are just lying on the ground. Not only that I have trouble crafting because i don't have an instant idea of what reasources i already have and and what i need to craft new items and even build buildings.


I guess what I think the game really needs right now is for the hearthlings to become more intilligent and autnomous so that they're always doing something productive other than restocking the stockpile when i'm not giving orders.


These are all things i think should be dealt with as the game updates. Quite frankly i'm impressed that the game is set to continue running depsite all the erros and bugs that pop up which is of course a clear indication that the game still needs some polishing. But I am sure that once this game is eventually completed it should become something very fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing Stonehearth since very early access (Alpha 2 roughly). It has been a true joy to watch this game grow from the core mechanics into what it is now.

I will not say that the game is complete or necessarily good. There is a lot of content still to implement, features to add and polish to be put in, but as it stands, Stonehearth is playable and offers several hours worth of gameplay in its current state. Given the price of almost $30, I would not recommend buying it unless you want into the early access system. The game does not, currently, have $30 worth of content.

In spite of that, I do strongly recommend this game, both now and most likely when it leaves early access. The team is dedicated and communication is open and transparent. The game's modability is very good and new content rolls out every few weeks, showing that development is definitely active and lively.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you quite like sandbox games where you build and mine, this is not the game for you. This game is worth $5. If you are looking for an interesting game to play that are similar I would reccommend Gnomoria, Craft The World, and Banished. Totally worth the money. reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
Too exensive for so little content.


In itself the game has a lot of potential. Basically it is a RTS Minecraft more or less. You decide what your villagers build, what furniture or weapons they craft etc etc.

Sadly, the content so far is very limited. And it does not feel like there is any progress in this regard.
After the first few nights it feels like there is nothing left to do. You have accomodation, a few farms and traps and a small military squad to fend off invaders.
From that point onward it is literally just wathing your villagers eat and sleep.

If the devs would add more content this would definitely be a recommendation. But in its current state the game is way too expensive.

Stonehearth is a overall great game, with lots of potential to make it better. The only problem I have encountered is that it some computers can't handle it and will lag out and possibly lose your world. ITS A GAME. Here are the pros and cons, pros run well (most of the time) the animals and people are cute looking, you can get a lot of people(I got at least twenty eight in the alpha) there is a lot of exploring and the goblins look ridiculous. Cons (everyone likes these) :steammocking: after your town gets bigger it starts lagging more, the goblin raids can be devastating and I think there needs to be more weapons. Overall a good game that I highly recommend to everyone. :steamhappy:

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince alpha 16, this game is definitely one of the best to get on Steam. It already had a lot of special features before, giving you the feeling to play Minecraft inside visuals that reminded me of Final Fantasy tactics... and not only the beautiful Indie graphic style, but the whole job system reminded me that game I loved. And then the combat update (alpha 16) just bring the game to a whole new level. There's a story line, a scenario where clans of orcs and goblins will come and try to take you out after offering you to pay tribute or be killed. You have the choice. This is an open-world-Indie-RPG-sandbox-Minecraft-style-realtime-strategy game that is definitely worth trying ! You can choose to explore and fight in almost non-stop action or choose the peaceful mode or just hit the pause button while you design slowly a whole civilization block by block with all the details you want to add. You can dig your hole through the mountain and keep hiding there or just build the biggest castle in the middle of a big lake with bridges and secret tunels... it's all up to you! Alpha 16 is now super stable and incredibly polished for an alpha release. Stop what you're doing and just try this game now ! ;)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe devs put their heart and souls into this game, and it shows! They're always adding in new and intersesting features and complete a new alpha release every month or so. It's nice to have a game where you can build whatever you want while defending it from the various and expanding array of monsters. I love the RPG elements of needing a previous class in order to advance further. Or a different class is needed to craft the necessary tool to level up a hearthling. Alpha games have lots of bugs you say? Fear not! Many of the game-breaking bugs or annoying bugs that I experienced when I first bought this game are all gone or at least are being addressed and steps are being made toward fixing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a big fan of games like Minecraft and Civilization I decided to buy Stonehearth even though it is only an Alpha. I am very impressed from playing so far (Alpha v11), yes there are bugs which can be game breaking and there is so much more that needs to be added, but this really has the beginnings of a good game. I've done a couple of play throughs and am getting the hang of managing the little town and it is very addictive. At the moment there is a bit of a lack of things to do at the later stages of the game, mining for minerals has only recently been added and beyond upgrading gear doesn't seem to have much purpose, but I'm sure more will be added.

Of course, it is still in Alpha so there are many issues that can be annoying, the AI of your workers can be poor at times and they can just get stuck doing nothing. I think it would really benefit this game to allow some control over individual workers, or at least allow some prioritization of tasks because at the moment it is a bit frustrating when for example you want a worker to pick something up that he's stood next to but he just doesn't do it.

These bugs aside the game is very promising and I will certainly be following its development closely. If bugs annoy you then I would wait for the retail version. If, like me, you like the look of the game and can't wait, then I don't think you'll be disappointed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA cute little game. The art and play style are very endearing very quickly, and it's a good way to spend a few hours relaxing. My only real complaint is that ATM, it's somewhat limited and repetitive. I hope to eventually see some greater variety in building types, not just living and eating spaces, and maybe some more goals you have to meet in order to gain your next villager. But overall, I'd recommend this even if you don't like Early Access games. This is one that gets better and more interesting with each new build.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite being in Alpha, this game has already come a long way.

I've been playing Stonehearth for quite a long time now and it has never ceased to please me. The game's developers are active and it gets updated frequently, which is always great to see. Many things inside the game are customisable, such as the design of your buildings.

My ONLY grudge are the bugs and errors that sometimes occur, but being in Alpha this is fully understandable, and the devs really seem to pay attention to their community and knuckle down those pesky things.

They have a great concept and I can only see it getting better from here. If you're a fan of the town-building/defense genre with money to spend, look no further than Stonehearth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun in concept but garbage in reality, the AI is crap and often abandons jobs or mining sites for no reason and you gotta struggle trying to figure out a way to get them to clear that piece of land or finish building a certain building. And often they will refuse to remove the structures no matter how many times you command them to remove it. Only hope at that point is to start a new game or have a village that looks half abandoned.

So it's all inconvenient

When the game actually works, it works well, but until it's updated futher it's not really something I'd reccomend, the games description and screenshots hype it up a lot more than it needs to be, as do the reviews. The game will be fixed in a matter of decades, early access games have a habbit of not being completed or living up to the real potential or hype, like most kickstarter campaigns.

tldr; gay game

Early Access Review

I might change this with further updates but as of now i wouldn't reccomend getting this.
When i bought this i thought it would be a bit like a minecrafty version of Rimworld but its not really.
It's like rimworld but 1. the ai storyteller isn't trying to actively kill you ( a plus ) and 2. the building is realy realy horrible.
Everything and i mean everything is made using that new building button, so you end up with roads counting as a building.
Don't even get me started at making 2 floors or more.. i can't figure out how to make stairs at all, even though you think it would just be block on block right? not in this game.
So what i do is i go into the mountain and make cave dwellings. this works rather well. Untill the lack of optimalisation kicks you in the teeth.
All in all it looks nice and it's fun to play but until they do some major optimising and some work on the building aspect i say go play Rimworld instead. It's not threedee and looks a lot like prison architect ( and last time i checked also still in alpha ) but at least the reason why your settlement dies out is because the game actively kills you not because your computer is getting strangled.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this a bunch last night, and plan to play a bunch more in the future. This is a fantastic little game. I can tell it still needs some work, but so far, pretty fun.
Things I wish were better:
-The camera is a little awkward, and I wish I could get on a power perspective to the ground sometimes, since the animations and art are so damned cute, it would be nice to be a little closer to the inhabitants.
----It would almost be worth it to have a 'walk around' mode, where you can 'be' one of the characters
-When you have a blueprint for a building, and don't build exactly the required item for your specified blueprint there is no way of knowing, and the workers will not override one door for another, and if you decided to manually place items into the build, the ghosty blueprint remains
-Items like fences don't 'auto complete' the way I wish they would, and leave gaps
-I wish you could follow around a specific character, and their overlay wouldn't cover up the entire screen.

Anyway...that is what I noticed so far....I will be building adorable little towns soon...and I am sure I will find little irksome quirks. But, that won't stop me from playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Purchased the game 9 days ago after watching it for months.  It is way over priced at $24.99 for what you get in return.  The game is fantastic up to the point where you get numerous engine error messages.  The game completely freezes up after about 60-90 minutes of play.  No crashing, game just pretty much stops.  Now you can either check on the game every 10 -15 minutes and see if any of the people have moved or start a new game.  Starting a new game just puts you back into the position of having the same freezing game problem in another 60-90 minutes.  I have played on the 11 build and the 12 build version and the freezing problem happens on both vesions.  Hope this will get fixed so the game is playable rather than the DEVS adding in more content.  The portion of the game that I could play was really great, would just like to be able to actually play it longer and see what the people can actually do.

This is not on my end as I run an AMD FX 8350  Eight Core Processor   4 GHz  8 GB Ram   64 Bit Operating System  Win 10.  My drivers are always kept current.

All in all; a great game to sit down and ponder about how to want to decide the next step of your small colony

Basically Minecraft meets Sims

- Promoting Shepards to war animal trainers (wolves, bears, lions that turn on you if not fed)
- Promoting basic foot soldiers soldiers to generals and bowman
- Refrigerators or ice boxes to keep food from spoiling so fast
- Tougher enemy progressions

reviewText:
Early Access Review

$25 will buy you five large cups of coffee. I would rather have the coffee than this game.

+An interesting game that has potential if the devs come through on their promises
+Lots of possibilities for creative projects
+The best minecraft clone out there that isn't trying to be minecraft
+A nice aesthetic

-Characters move super slow even during fast forward speeds

-You start with a map of the generated world, then must choose a terribly small section of it to be your entire game world.

-The building system is difficult and unforgiving. Small mistakes means you have to scrap the entire building plan (alpha issue)

-Very unstable with frequent bugs ending entire game worlds (alpha issue)

-Currently a very real lack of content outside of the buggy building system (alpha issue)

-The game has been in dev for five years but they are still in the alpha stages and they have announced that they intend to start making other games. They've really done a good job keeping frequent contact with the community but I'm worried they will eventually abandon this project all together if the seams cant hold it together.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Strongly unrecommend, unless you are a game developer just need to know how it works.

It all started with taking like 2 hours googling just how to get into the game, because it crashes when I start it.

This game often crashes and I lose hours of progress -- for some reason auto-saving is not working sometimes. It's a really fun game, but bugs bugs bugs bugs. I crashed 3 times in one hour, that's 3 resets of progress.

The UI have problems of the last century: key leaking -- if you press a key that have a binding when you are typing text, that binded function gets triggered. For example numeral key 1 2 and 3 are for game speed, so everytime you enter a number with 1, 2 or 3 in it the game speed changes. This should simply never happen anymore. What kind of idiot does that?

AI is stupid. My blacksmith insists on putting ingots on the ground despite there's a crate next to him that only accepts metal.

To be honest at this time I simply doubt the developers have what it takes to make it right, because if you have these types of error, it's typically the code underlying is a mess. It's flawed in its design from the beginning. it could take longer to fix the bugs than rewriting everything.

How many other early access games do you know that update it AT LEAST once a week, ESPECIALLY with a studio of this size.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great, but there are some things that would be nice to see.

There should be difficulty settings, they could edit things like how long before enemies begin to attack, or how powerful the enemies are.
There is no way, that i've seen, to make specific units do specific tasks.
It would also be nice to be able to set patrol paths for footmen.
The terrain seems very blocky which does not meet the expectations of the thumbnail.
Also, how do I equip my units with other items?

All of these complaints are to taken with a grain of salt, I know that it is difficult to make games, and I know that Early Acess does not improve that. In addition I know that as an early acess game, it is not done. This is just a list of things to consider.

All notes to the developer aside, this game comes highly recommended and has been one of the only games I've continued playing for long periods of time lately.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Purchased Stoneheart about half a year ago when it was still in an earlier phase of developement.
Team Radiant is doing good work, the updates are coming steady and the Forums got an active community.

The game itself is... from my POV a mix out of minecraft and dungeon kepper.
Where you pile up the blocks in minecraft yourself, here you assign a silly crowd of beings to a schedule to terraform the world in a way you want it to be.

Design your own Buildings from the very scratch. Or dig. DIG! and build the dwarven settlement you always imagined.

Personally, only played in Peaceful mode so far. Reminds of Settlers in the Free Settlement Mode.

Hopefully, as its displayed on Stonehearths website, there is a multiplayer support to come.

PS: This game is very RAM intensive, and even made a 16gb RAM machine crash once, from lacking memory.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has potential but the delopers are just bad and they should feel bad. Maybe when this game is complete it will be better but for now, DO NOT PURCHASE! I actually want a refund.

The developers definitily should not be relying on LUA for so much of their code. It should just be used to allow easy modding. Their use of it is the main problem, it seriously limits the performance capabilities of the game.

There are many other problems now that they can solve easily. Such as building editor and then the engine that gets the 'hearthlings' to build. From my understaning, they are already working on this. But progress is slow, and instead of concentrating on important issues such as this, they instead release updates that add useless hats (which are nice but not a priority).

If they reduce their dependency on LUA and improve performance, I would be inclined to change my review. The rest of the little bugs do not bother me as much.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From what I've seen, this game has amazing potential and is fun as of now.

The good:
graphics are cute and run fairly well,
custom buildings are easy to make,
fairly easy to pick up and play

The bad:
BUGS, lots of em
whenever someone gets a new job their heads are absorbed into their torso!
when crafting, I have no idea if I have the proper materials in storage. I have to pull up a seperate tab that blocks the craft button!
There's not a lot of job options (yet)
The villagers tend to forget what they're doing if they go too far away from home
The Ui is kinda sticky with no way to quickly check on villagers

Suggestions:
Race options, a village with just humans can be boring. why not throw in some other races with new benefits?
have two story houses
a tutorial would be nice
have morale specific things, I don't really know how to raise morale other than with food and beds
make mining more precise. when selecting what to mine it looks like i'm mining the ground when I should be mining the wall!
more enemies!


Overall, I'm enjoying this game. I hope to see good things in the future!
current rating: 5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game looking for a good city/town builder type of game with crafting and rpg elements. So far I've really enjoyed it. I think it really has the potential to become a very good game as development continues.

The game looks great, has good replayability, and looks to be frequently updated. I love that there's a building designer! The crafting is good so far as well.

The downside is that it's early access which means there are a lot of bugs, some of which require you to start a new game due to their severity (but the game is so replayable that it's not that big of a deal right now) and there are features that are not finished or not implemented yet. The UI is also a little clunky and there are some quality of life features I would desperately like to see rolled out soon.

I would definitely recommend if you don't mind early access and bugs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review: 16/07/15 Alpha 11 Unstable(Early Access)

Stonehearth has, like many in the game type the ability to become something great. It is by it's self at this stage not much better or worse than any other, but it does have dedicated devs on its side. It will like most games in Early Access, be given as much love as possible and with a positive community behind it will grown into something great.

The newest build release adds a lot of fixes and features to the game and is beggining to pad it out. With the addition of the cook we finaly see some end food processing. We need to continue to play these build and find the bugs, this will make the game a better product between patches. Bug fixes and staility issues continue to be worked on. I would like to see in the next patch a build that really helps the late game lag issues. As i do notice from 14 plus people in my village it becomes to slow down a little. The most i have been able to get to without it beocming unplayable is 22/23, and i would like to reach a lot higher.

I love the style and game play. and i like the new inventory and character sheet system. The devs are listening to the players and are revolveing the game not only around their concept and ideas but the players ideas for changing and improving. The best thing about a game in early access is the fact the devs can actually to do this. As well as this some of the better finihsed games out of early access have done just that, listened to the players.

Really looking forward to the progression of the game. At present i do recommend it even in its early access stage. Get involved by playing and chat to the community, they are great.

Please not that there are still lots of bugs and issues with the game. I would definitely watch a Lets Play on Youtube or watch a broadcast before buying. Other than that have fun :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this a bunch last night, and plan to play a bunch more in the future. This is a fantastic little game. I can tell it still needs some work, but so far, pretty fun.
Things I wish were better:
-The camera is a little awkward, and I wish I could get on a power perspective to the ground sometimes, since the animations and art are so damned cute, it would be nice to be a little closer to the inhabitants.
----It would almost be worth it to have a 'walk around' mode, where you can 'be' one of the characters
-When you have a blueprint for a building, and don't build exactly the required item for your specified blueprint there is no way of knowing, and the workers will not override one door for another, and if you decided to manually place items into the build, the ghosty blueprint remains
-Items like fences don't 'auto complete' the way I wish they would, and leave gaps
-I wish you could follow around a specific character, and their overlay wouldn't cover up the entire screen.

Anyway...that is what I noticed so far....I will be building adorable little towns soon...and I am sure I will find little irksome quirks. But, that won't stop me from playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

$25 will buy you five large cups of coffee. I would rather have the coffee than this game.

+An interesting game that has potential if the devs come through on their promises
+Lots of possibilities for creative projects
+The best minecraft clone out there that isn't trying to be minecraft
+A nice aesthetic

-Characters move super slow even during fast forward speeds

-You start with a map of the generated world, then must choose a terribly small section of it to be your entire game world.

-The building system is difficult and unforgiving. Small mistakes means you have to scrap the entire building plan (alpha issue)

-Very unstable with frequent bugs ending entire game worlds (alpha issue)

-Currently a very real lack of content outside of the buggy building system (alpha issue)

-The game has been in dev for five years but they are still in the alpha stages and they have announced that they intend to start making other games. They've really done a good job keeping frequent contact with the community but I'm worried they will eventually abandon this project all together if the seams cant hold it together.
voteText: 46 of 92 people (50%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really really like this game and look forward to see where the development will lead it. Nice voxelbased world to build and survive in. I bought the game somewhere around Juni-Juli 2015 I think and played for a while and recently played some more and wow. They had really improved the game a lot. Much more stable, so far after these months I haven't had a single crash or save that had to be abandoned. Not only have the stability improved but some more content has been added and you can really see the long gameplay to take shape. There is still much more to be done but so far the developers have proved to me that they are working hard and they well deserved the money I droped for this game. There is also an active modding community which is always a big plus in my book.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very Addictive game!!

Basically Minecraft meets Sims

I am very addicted to this game and feel like it will be great once it is finished. However, only 13 hours into the game with only 19 villagers and my game suffers HUGE lag spikes and FPS drops especially at night. I run a decent PC core i5 with 8GB of RAM but the SIM lag drops to almost unplayable levels.

I am very glad i purchased this game simply to support the developers and look forward to when it is finished.

Ideas for developers:
- Promoting Shepards to war animal trainers (wolves, bears, lions that turn on you if not fed)
- Promoting basic foot soldiers soldiers to generals and bowman
- Refrigerators or ice boxes to keep food from spoiling so fast
- Tougher enemy progressions

Early Access Review

the concept of the game is nice, if they ever complete a working game.

it's an alpha, I understand, however it feels like the devs just add/change stuff and then throw it out without even playtesting it once. The nr of easily found (game breaking) bugs by just playing the game once is crazy, even more crazy that they throw it out like that.
what they expect ? that 100 people find the same bug and then take the effort to report it in their own way ? While a developer + debugtools + normal playthrough will be 100x more efficient in understanding the majority of the obvious bugs and then fixing it.
IMO we're to make this game monkey proof, not report that a carpenter/cook/blacksmith just forgets his job and then see no fix for it in subsequent releases. I mean c'mon, did they even play their own alpha game ONCE ??!?!


Next, the devs are caught by the 'multiplayer syndrome', insofar everything has to be #$%^&&&% multiplayer these days so they made a client-server architecture to prepare for it.
Now looking at the nr of obvious bugs every release I get a simcity 4 feeling : How to f**k over a great gameconcept by making it multiplayer/client-server.
all over again.....


do yourself a favor and wait for the finished product, currently it's aggravating as hell.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Purchased the game 9 days ago after watching it for months.  It is way over priced at $24.99 for what you get in return.  The game is fantastic up to the point where you get numerous engine error messages.  The game completely freezes up after about 60-90 minutes of play.  No crashing, game just pretty much stops.  Now you can either check on the game every 10 -15 minutes and see if any of the people have moved or start a new game.  Starting a new game just puts you back into the position of having the same freezing game problem in another 60-90 minutes.  I have played on the 11 build and the 12 build version and the freezing problem happens on both vesions.  Hope this will get fixed so the game is playable rather than the DEVS adding in more content.  The portion of the game that I could play was really great, would just like to be able to actually play it longer and see what the people can actually do.

This is not on my end as I run an AMD FX 8350  Eight Core Processor   4 GHz  8 GB Ram   64 Bit Operating System  Win 10.  My drivers are always kept current.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seriously I cannot say enough good things about this game.  The best early access Fort-like experience you can get in 3D.  This game and Gnomoria are the best Fort-likes on Steam.  The  dev's on Stonehearth are constantly adding new content and the recent update with a new playable Kingdom type and terrain just reminded me how much I love this game.  There are a few more playable races in the pipe if I'm not mistaken, and multiplayer! Oh I cannot wait till MP.  (It is not MP right now to be clear.)

I'm an EA who ore but this is one of the ones I would recommend with no reservations.

In the game you plop down a group of curated settlers in a hospitable or inhospitable landscape and have a solid town building survival experience.  Give Hearthlings jobs and watch as they level up, then you can promote them into higher tier professions.  With awesome mods like Candledark you can really add some variety to your game.  The community is great and I've got nothing but respect for these devs that regularly live stream their work on ye old Twitchbox.

Edit: They added more classes!!!!
I (still) love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you've ever wanted to create a village/kingdom with control over crafters and defenders, farmers and the sizes of farms, locations and the ability to move those fields. This is for you.

First let me start with the cons -
1) This is Alpha and does not represent the end product.
2) It's not finished yet and has bugs.

And now the pros in my opinion -
1) Ability to set where you want to start your village.
2) Ability to determine who is right for the jobs available.
3) Ability to change jobs of your Hearthlings (townsfolk).
4) Ability to custom build any building and save the template.
5) Ability to place stockpiles inside of buildings for protection against raiders.

There are many game aspects that I have not listed, but I hope I have at least touched up on some important deciding factors for potential backers. I love the game and can't wait for the release.

With that in mind, every Tuesday they have a post Desktop Tuesday"
date: it's a great place to see what the team has been working on
recommended:
and don't forget to check their website for additional information.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A couple notes on playing the game;

Have at least 1-2 Farmers. Once you make one of them a cook, they help harvest, but you still need them to plow the fields.

Workers are VERY much so necessary. Although the carpenter, potter, mason and other occupations do help build/haul, you're going to want to keep the people with low-ranks down on the worker size (1, 1 and 2 for the body/mind/spirit; Keep them a worker)

Fighters and such need to be the most populace unit category (Archers, Knights and Footmen); At least have one of each with an herbalist. (For the three, high Body and Mind. Mostly so they don't run like cowards)

Herbalist and Cleric; Have one of each. One heals while the villagers sleep/get into beds, one heals just by walking around/in combat. (High spirit for these guys is necessary)

All Worker-class" occupations need mind and spirit. All three are much so needed for the farmers than anything.

ALWAYS. ALWAYS remember there's a pause button that lets you keep playing. Helps you plan things.

Town watch; Love it
hoursPlayed: remember to turn it off after everyone is done fighting.\n\nAlways go after goblin camps/"stray monsters" after the next invasion summon (Ents/Golems/Etc)
voteText: that way your villagers aren't defenseless."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Current level of recommend?
Strong Follow!

If your interested in the game I'd give it a follow and check back in a couple months. Game is still very early alpha and most of the updates are focused on making the game more stable while adding in one thing at a time. In its current state for its price, your looking at maybe a weekend or a couple sessions worth of game time. Updates are a bit slow but are pretty steady in frequency. Been playing stonehearth on and off since alpha 5 and the game does have quite a bit of potential (devs are also active on their forums which is a plus)

If you do choose to pick it up just remember the early access tag means early access. In its current state you be able to play around with the basics but will likely run into bugs/glitches your village grows. Also, its a good idea to save before you start a new building that way you can reload your save should you run into any bugs/issues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was an original Kickstarter backer back in mid 2013.

The development of this game has long passed estimated release times. It still gets updates but they don't add much. Save games aren't stable between versions. Mod support has still yet to surface. OSX/Linux versions are on the backburner and may never come yet they were one of the first stretch goals.

The game itself is hardly what I would call playable. Here's a list of the many things that go wrong:
* Construction of buildings stalls. This means they never complete a building, which is a pretty important aspect.
* Villagers consistently fail on their tasks meaning you have to re-task them. Again, and again, and again.

And of course at one point in the game the AI just stops.

I do not recommend the game as early access. One day if it gets a full release then maybe I would recommend it.

I can't imagine the devs adding something that makes the gameplay interesting enough to warrant the $25 pricetag. They would have to add a whole new game element or something.

6/10 at most, it got very very boring rather quickly. If I put more hours in and change my mind, I might update this review.

The user can't select on the verticle plane.  Well they can select the horizontal plane.  Good enough for early access.

....etc.

I get that the devs want to put in more features

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game reminds me of Dwarf Fortress. Its great to have everything animated and all but the content included is very low and it starts to get laggy at around 15 hearthlings.

3 hours in and I'm wondering why I don't go play Dwarf Fortress instead.

I can see this game becoming good but it's going to need a lot more content and optimization before its worth it.

Pros:
Animated Dwarf Fortress
You can click objects in-game
Crafting system is easily accessible

Cons:
Lack of Content
Workshops are hard to find (you have to find the item when its crafted, to place)
Laggy at around 15 Hearthlings

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment I don't recommend to buy this game! After I first installed it, I could start the game und play my first round, but after like 2 hours the game started heavily lagging and after I restarted the game it always brings up an error message and I can't play anymore. I really expected more for an early access game that costs over 20€!!!

So here are a few things I can tell about the game:
+ The building system is very interesting. You have a managing system where you generate a building and then the little fellows start build it. You don't have to worry about that anymore as long as you have enough ressources. Even the scaffolding is made by their own.
+ The job managing is also very simple. You have a good overview over the little fellows and which jobs they are doing. Some of the jobs have a question mark, but I guess they will be implemented over time since this is game is still in developing.
+ Ah! Finally there is a game where you know what you have to do to get new citizens :D So every morning there appears a message which shows your food, wealth and a third thing which I stupidly forgot :P If you reach the value for the new citizen you can directly accept or decline it and he will automatically enter your town.

- Mining into a mountain can be a bit annoying since the control is a bit buggy or maybe I did it the wrong way. Anyway I had to zoom with the camera to the ground and then follow the path through the mountain to select a new area to mine. If I go a little bit to far left or right I'm hanging in the mountain and I have to zoom out and do the same again.
- Many bugs and errors which make the game unplayable, like the lagging or the error message which doesn't let my play again.

Nevertheless while I managed to play the game it was really good. Since I'm a fan of the survival/building/crafting genre I really hope that this game will be playable within the next patch again. I have high expections in this game and I really want to see what the next patches are bringing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I try out a lot of early access games and expect them to be a bit rough around the edges. Unfortunately this game is so rough, with so many bugs, that it's just too frustrating to play at the moment.

Even primary mechanics such as building are broken (you have to access the console and type a code, just to remove a block) and the menus, of which there are too many, are a confusing and convoluted mess (when you switch to the next tab, the previous one will remain open, even though it's redundant now). There's no master delete button, so lots of menus hide their relevant remove/delete/undo functions somewhere within them, which is different for each individual task or item. You would have to play a ton of hours to remember where they all are, so you spend a lot of time clicking around in order to perform what should be very basic, simple funtions. Every ten or fifteen minutes an error will also pop up on screen, but most of the time I have no idea what they mean.

Lastly, that addictive hook that most creative games have isn't quite there yet. I don't think the game does a good job of showing off it's best assets, ideas and goals. It doesn't nudge you towards it's strengths in the way that even minimalist games like Minecraft manage to do.

I'd hold off for now if I was you. I have a good feeling about this game, but right now it's buggy, frustrating and a little bit bland.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been looking at this game for a while now, something told me to stay away from it, but I gave in and grabbed it on a city builder binge. I'm sad that I did.

I like the defence/survival element of Stonehearth, where camps of enemies will spawn around the map and periodically attack your settlement, you can either attack them early and risk your guards, or just wait out the attacks for the XP. There are also loot boxes and such around the map to be discovered, usually guarded by some mini-boss creatures. That part they did right, it's fun.

For a game that's been in development for such a long time, I really wonder why there are so many bugs. I understand it's a early access game, but that's not really an excuse for the really terrible building mechanics. It's a city-builder game, if i was developing a city builder, the first thing i'd get sorted would be the building mechanics, at the moment they're extremely frustrating and unintuitive. You have no ability to change things once you've placed them, so if you want to extend your wall out by 2 squares, you need to undo everything you've done to get back there. This is really frustrating when building and planning complex structures.

I'd like to see defensive walls (properly) added, or at least the ability to create stand-alone walls outside of the custom structure editor, for a simple project like a perimeter wall the player shouldn't be forced to stuff around too much. I noticed also that it's very clumbsy at sticking to things. i tried to incorporate a pre-existing structure in my town into the wall, instead the custom structure editor decided that the sections of wall touching that building now belonged to it, and not my wall, so the only way to get rid of those walls was to destroy that building. Annoying to say the least.

Along with numerous bugs that caused my workers to get stuck on window ledges, placing objects is a real pain. I've been forced to build a cobblestone fence piece-by-piece because if i try to place more than one at a time, the workers freak out and wont complete the task.

At this point I can't reccommend the game, I feel like I was ripped off, to be honest.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note: This is an early access review.

I tried Stonehearth on a whim after I had sworn to myself that I would never play an Early Access game ever again. This game has simply reaffirmed my convictions in this matter.

This is not to say that this game is terrible - it's not. It has potential, and there are a lot of good things about it. It has cute animations, enchanting music, and a nice crisp graphic style (although I must admit that the minecraft-esque aesthetic is getting a little old at this point).

As for how it plays, it is a minecraft derivative (not necessarily a bad thing), though instead of building and defending your settlement by yourself, you must order AI-controlled peons to do it for you. This would seem to be an excellent premise on paper, and sometimes it works beautifully. Watching your peons work, collect, harvest, eat, sleep and fulfill their tasks is sometimes very rewarding.

However, in many other ways, this game leaves something to be desired. The UI is confusing, tutorials are nonexistent, the camera controls are clunky, the building tools are even clunkier, and the minion AI is so glitchy that they will fail to build even the simplest of structures. Even the basic building designs that are shipped with the game will be left incomplete by your peons once they start building - even if they have all of the materials available. This forces you to scrap those structures and attempt to rebuild them again, and of course there's no guarantee that your peons will actually finish them the second time they try.

Other crippling bugs include peons who will simply freeze in place and refuse to move. Even when they become exhausted and start to starve, they won't move even to help themselves. The only way I've found to fix this is to reassign them to another job, but in doing so, they lose all of their accumulated levels. Not fun!

Issues like these are a bit concerning, considering that the game is over halfway through Early Access by now. But even with the bugs aside, Stonehearth seems to be sorely lacking in content. The plain, empty expanses of the landscape really aren't very stimulating, and there's very little to do out there. Once you get your settlement up and running (and it's not hard to do), you will simply repel invader attacks over and over again, collect whatever loot they drop, and continue to farm your crops.

This might actually be fun if the inventory management was enjoyable, but it's not. You can't really manipulate the objects in-game directly, so you have to rely on your peons to manage and care for the plethora of items that you will craft and collect. Usually this means that they will throw them into an unsorted jumble within your stockpile; other times, they will squirrel it away in crates and boxes, and if you have more than one, it will be anyone's guess as to which one they've put it in. If one of your items is missing and you can't seem to track it down, good luck finding it!

Stonehearth gave me a few moments of fun within the hours that I played it, but mostly I just felt bored and frustrated. It's a shame, because I really like the idea behind it. I may revisit it once it leaves Early Access, but if what I've seen is indicative of the final product, I could probably take it or leave it.

The good news is that the developers are providing regular updates, and are obviously very dedicated to this project. It should improve over time. I really hope it does.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have to say that the game is an amazing idea. Almost everthing they have done with the game is perfect. The art design, music, and the UI are all really good. There are a few down sides that are game breaking though. 1. The game has been in alpha for a long time, sure updates have been coming out but not as often as you would like. 2. The really bad thing about this game is that when you jump right in, it doesnt take long for you to realize that there are some really serious and obvious game breaking bugs. A really big bug that ruins this game for me is the entire User Interface disapearing like a fart in the wind. You start clicking buttons and moving your mouse in hopes that it returns... but it never does. You can still hear the action sounds of menues opening a closing. Another terrible bug that can just make you want to rip your hair out is the view hotkeys that allow you to view through buildings and even the ground. Sometimes once you have pressed that hotkey you're stuck in that view and you can't see anything. You can keep pressing the hotkey again but nothing usually happens. If you really want to pay to be a betta tester then go ahead and get the game, but just remember these bugs may never get fixed and the game may never be completely finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was one of the original kickstarter backers. This summer will be the end of the third year (going on the 4th) since this game has been in development. To say the progress has been slow would be an understatement. Triple A games take less time to develop than this has and it is still far away from release. Very little content because so much time has been spent constantly fixing things that should have been fixed in the early alpha's.

A lot of the bugs have been with this game since Alpha 1. Especially with AI. They have fixed AI building at least 3 or 4 times and it still doesn't work right. They have to keep going back and rewriting code over and over again.

They are nice developers but watching this game being developed has been amatuer hour. I was really into this game the first year watching all the dev streams and such but then it became obvious that it was going to be one of the longest development cycles in the history of gaming and I lost interest. Here it is - March of 2016 and they just had another stage of Alpha dedicated totally to bug fixing and fixing AI - Again!

This game is very charming and the music is top notch. It has such great potential but many of us have been waiting a very long time to see it realized and we are still waiting....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I love these type of sandbox/management games, this one seems to fall a little short. Originally, I bought this around the time I was playing Towns, and liked the idea that it was graphically superior to Towns and had a few more features in planning. Many features were still in development, but I don't mind supporting independent developers. Skip forward some months, and the problems inherent to this kind of development become self-evident. Even easy-concept games can be a nightmare when you start adding in features.

While the community is very strong and supportive, the developers communicate frequently and consistently, the game itself is fundamentally flawed. Gameplay is only tenable for about 12 hours, from there it's the same thing in a new setting. At the moment, many core features of the game are either uninteresting or broken. The engine itself is unsustainable or poorly written. AI still breaks itself after enough time has passed (or becomes so inept at tasks they become useless). Town areas are by default limited to 20 citizens, because the engine really can't handle much more than that. The map bogs down after about 10 in-game days with very little activity (2 gb ram and 16% of a decent quad-core processor on PAUSE).

If you're looking to purchase this game, wait. See if the developers iron out the bugs, but even then know that it's likely not going to be a game you're going to come back to or play for too long. It'll be something casual when you've got nothing else to do - download, install, play, get bored and repeat in a couple months.

Pros:
- Good looking UI and general landscape - blocky but tastefully done.
- Good conceptual design of core elements.
- Good balance between difficulty vs. reward - easy enough for new players, but can't immediately make everything.
- Consistent small updates, if a little slow for what the updates usually are.
- Consistent and constructive communication from developers and community.
- Implemented crash reporting that actually means something will get fixed eventually.

Cons:
- AI bogs very quickly.
- Processor hungry for package size.
- Gameplay can get repetitive (not talking about unimplemented features).
- Spend much time after initial rush just watching your citizens do things.
- Buggy as hell, but to be expected in Alpha.
- Gameplay is geared to non-expansion - there's no reason to really expand much beyond starting area. Just pick a good one and wall yourself in.
- Gameplay itself is very short. When you've done it once, it's the same thing on a different map.

tl;dr:
Wait a while if you're following this game. It's buggy and VERY casual. Devs are slow, but do communicate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, Picture Gnomoria, but with better graphics, better UI, and Papa Johns Delivers.

Now you have your delicious or disgusting pizza, depending on where you live, and you can start your crafting and managing and building journey to keep your citizens alive. The crafting system is very simple and easy to learn, while still being of a good size for this early on in development. The raids on your town can be very simple and easy to fend off, to brutal cavity defiling, child sodomising, soul endingly devastating. So always make sure you have a Fighter or two ASAP. Focus on getting them better equipment over getting your next crafting milestone. Your people can live on without a Trapper for a few more weeks. They won't be living if a horde of goblins kill your Defenders and then your people because all they have for equipment is still padded armor and wooden sword and shield.


This game is very much still in progress but I like the progress thats being done. Most games in early access that say they are still in Alpha (Which this one tells you it is right at the start) have half the content, and 1,000 times more bugs and crashes. All this has that I've noticed so far is a couple of UI and AI bugs and logic loops, and a small tendancy for data leak. So restart your game every hour and a half or so and you will be fine. Also you have to turn on Auto Save, which was weird. Sometimes your Citizens will go to move an object you designated to be moved elsewhere and someone else will get to it sooner and that previous citizen will still go to where that object is. Though once they find out the object is there they move on to the next objective which is nice. Sometimes in Gnomoria (A finished and released game) Gnomes will do the exact same thing but instead get stuck in an AI Loop and you pretty much have to wait for them to get hungry or tired to reset themselves.

So far the majority of negative reviews about this game are about buildings not being able to get fully done. In my opinion since I have a fully functioning town with 12 buildings, 5 of which are custom design, roads, pastures, lengthy defensive works and what not, all of them 100% completed. That the complainers are idiots, and that they try to do multiple projects at one time, run out of materials and then complain that the game is broken. Much like that meme where a guy rides a bike then puts a stick in his own tire and complains about someone else doing it. Your citizens will do multiple projects at a time, and the game will tell you that you have enough resources for a building if the resources are still in your stockpile. That means that if you pause the game, and try to construct 3 houses, each time it will tell you that you have enough resources in your stockpile. If you are that tired and don't notice that logic issue, please go to sleep. Or stop being a ♥♥♥♥♥.


A couple of suggestions that would be nice in my opinion.

-Make it to where when digging a mine tunnel, they auto construct ladders, since people will sometimes forget and well there goes 3-6 of your citizens.

-Possibly already in development but if there could be some sort of food preservation thing. Like an Ice box or something that will keep my fruits and veggies fresh longer would be nice.

- Lower the amount of food it takes to get a new Citizen at ALL levels. I am currently sitting at 15 Citizens and producing enough food for 80. Still can't get a new Citizen. I realize this may be due to the developers wanting to give people a possible Siege supply incase they take heavy losses to Food or Food production capability from a raid, but there is an option wether or not to accept a new Citizen. Let us take the risk.

-Developers. This tip more than all the others is the most important and I hope that if you read this review and take anything from it, that you take this one to the heart.

Give yourselves a pat on the back, and some high fives all around. You state clearly that this game is in alpha and its already so well done. I don't particularly enjoy games like this. Gnomoria is a bore and I couldnt stand to play it for more than 30 minutes. Any other game like this that involves city management with no Army management or Cities to pillage and conquer leave me bored and moving on to another game. YOU got me to play this for 4 hours so far, and once there is more content I can happily say I will gladly add 100 hours just to explore and enjoy this finely crafted game you have made. Good job, and keep it up.

Negatives

This seems to be the case here and prevents from really getting into building a massive city.

Recommended, but with a caveat...

I cant say as it is right now I find the game that enjoyable. The dev team has a lot of work to do to get the game finished, but its the dev team behind the game that makes me want to like this game. They constantly release new content that addresses mine and others issues with the game, and its progressing quickly.

In a few months I believe there will be enough substance to it to make it a really fun game. Get it only after taking a look at the devs homepage and deciding yourself if what they have planned still makes you want to buy it. Also note that its not a complete game as is and you will be playing a watered down version of what is to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been around since the beginning of this games origins on Kickstarter, and this game has evolved so much since then. While true, this game AS OF NOW is a little shoddy in some places. However, even with those problems the game remains to be a fun and enjoyable experience. The devs spend countless hours fixing bugs and moving the game forward, relesing beta updates on a weekly basis and constantly keeping the players informed, even taking in their suggestions on their dev stream and the Stonehearth forums. The game is, unlike most, being molded by not just the developers, but the players aswell. These qualities make me certain that this game will travel from the state it's in now, which is still a good game as is, to even grater heights.

4/5 would recommend AS IS.
5/5 would recommend for the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An another videogame with potential.
Created with the style of Trove and from the ashes of Cube World, Stoneheart is a strategy version of the two games and taking inspiration from other famous videogames like Imperium Civitas, Imperium Online and the Sims series.
You can take care of your settlement (if you keep up the good work you can make it into a real city), of your citizens, promote them to different jobs, making everyone of them an indispensable member of your progression and your city; however (if you choose the right mode) there is not always peace around here: train some soldiers to defend yourself from any menace (wolfes, goblins, undead, animated stones?!), kicking their butt or send a raiding party in order to loot and destroy enemy camps.
This game is still on Early Access and on the Alpha development and that means the develop is still open with ideas and I'm pretty sure that the final result will become a good rival and a strategy version of Trove

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a game to buy at this point. The devs make excuses to some very long time game breaking bugs. If you like restarting your game every 10 to 15 minutes to make it work, or losing whole towns because of errors.. then maybe this game is for you. In its current state it is unplayable and all the devs focus on is new content without correcting the game breaking bugs. What good is new content if you can't play the game?

Your town people will idle for no reason (stop working).
There is pathing issues that will make your town people die of hunger.
They will not complete buildings early in the game, this is for the simple designs forget trying to build complex buildings.
Restarting the game every 10 to 15 minutes in hopes it corrects the issues ( and most the time it does not).
It will use up your ram at high velocity and spam you with error messages (got over 5k a few times on error messages).

This is just a few examples of the state of this unplayable game. If they had a report game button I would hit it in a minute.

Be warned before dumping money into this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.


But for the review's sake, 9/10. The game is great, but pike all games it can be buggy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You know those over-ambitious games that you hear about and think they'd be amazing, but then you play them and are immediately dissapointed?  That's this game.
I got suckered in by the Kickstarter, and it's been the same glitchy mess for three years.

At its core, the game wants to be a city-planning, strategy, completely customizable dream of a game with strong community support.  The problem is that, at the moment, there's very little customization, no strategy, and no real city planning.  Towns rarely last long enough to build more than a handful of homes before glitches break a save.
The new features that have been added over the years have been nice, but they'd be nicer if I could actually enjoy them without having to restart because of a game-breaking bug.

One of two things will happen.  Either your adorable hearthlings will simply stop doing anything, or some problem will arise when building a structure and nothing will be accomplished as all citizens will get stuck on a ladder or permanently be stuck holding materials or literally lose their head.

Some bugs are fixed, but the game hasn't progressed nearly far enough while in development, and now that Riot bought the company, I sincerely doubt anything will come of this game.

tl;dr - If the game didn't break so much, it'd be a fun little time waster as it is, but that's a pretty big if" at this point."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The concept is fantastic, and there's a lot of potential in the game, but...

There's far too many issues with its current state. Building custom buildings is near-impossible, the controls are often non-responsive, there's a nasty memory leak (this game should not require +6 gigs of RAM), and that's only the biggest problems. Workers that don't work, ladders and furniture that can't be deconstructed, etc. There's many small things that combine to make the game very hard to enjoy.

Putting aside the bugs and building problems, the game is well designed. The progression of your minions is simple but effective, the resource harvesting likewise. My only quibble is that it takes a very long time to do anything with only a 2x speed option. I'd like the ability to go up to 8x at least.

Given the strength of the underlying design, I look forward to playing the game more once it's had some bug-fixing done. However, I can only review it based on what it is now, so I cannot recommend this as is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has some potential but due to several (gamebreaking) bugs it is barely playable.
For a game with a focus on building stuff, one would expect the builing mechanics to work more or less (early acess or not) but it really does not. Most builings (which are slightly more complicated than: four wall + roof) wil not get finished or the building tool will kinda crash. The inability to remove buildings does not help.
The worker AI is also very glitchy and in most cases a (pretty annoying) reload of the game helps, but not always...

So, what do i think about the game?
I like the overall setting and i also like the simplistic graphis style. I think, this game has a lot of potential and will be very good + addicting, when its finished.

Is it worth your money (leaving aside the early access nonsense)?
No, not yet -> too early access""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As far as potential goes I think this game has quite a bit, and while I would not reccomend the game as it is due to the reasons below, in time it should reach the point of being a worthwhile game for the current cost. Which is another thing..this game right now at most should be 15-20, since its not a game with a lot of content and with some major fatal bugs. Currently most lot of the planned content is no where near being in which makes me question the pricing decision. Right now only 1/3rd of the intended jobs are in.

During my five hours of gameplay I consantly ran into UI crashes and system failures, which would result in parts of the UI or game becoming unusable forcing you to reload. Twice now it has nearly crashed my pc to the point I was forced to do a false restart where the computer shuts the program down since you hit the power button but you then cancle the restart when it asks you to close your notepad. The game draws more ram then needed from your system causing sound glitches. Also combat in it can be frustraiting, having to use a badly designed party/designated area targeting system. And a warning, do NOT save when one of your characters is in direct combat, when you load the game takes a while to load the ui and seems to suddenly jump a minute or so ahead in combat, often instanly killing any non guard character without giving you the chance to react.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: 8-3-2015

Current version is even more unstable than before. It seems that the development team is going backwards each time they add a new feature.

-Multi-story housing construction nearly impossible.
-Roof construction causes severe Lua errors.
-Almost every game I've started becomes unplayable after a few hours of gameplay.

Avoid this title at the moment. I'd hardly call it Alpha.


Although I would normally recomend this game, I just can't justify recomending it for now. The idea is there, and the foundation of the game is more or less built, but it seems that the developer doesn't know what they want to do.
-Very little content. The addition of goblin packs and wolves have extended gameplay somewhat, but at best it is a bare minimum for your average game.
-The content in game is very repetitive.
-Extremely slow development schedule. It seems to me the developers are working on this either part time, or are severely short staffed. It can take months for systems to be completed, and usually once implemented are extremely buggy.
-Extremely buggy. Be prepared for constant crashes and damaged saves. I'm not certain with version 10+, but every new version requires a whole new game.
-Game is not what was advertised and has switched focus/goals. What originally was intended as a city/realm management game, has turned into a village micromanagement game.
-Game has lost focus in that it wants a combat RTS element, but still relies on its old villager micromanagement foundation.

It's a good idea and so far a solid foundation for what could be a great game in a few years (think Kerbal Space Program). I strongly recommend against purchasing at the moment or at full price. I would wait until it is either on sale, or it is much further along.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Almost all of the reviews so far are from people who have played the pre-Steam Early Access version a ton (I mean it was on Steam, just not publicly available) and I get why the like it, because it is a good game for what it is, but I'm going to not recommend it, not yet, because of what it claims to be, what the Kickstarter explained it to be, and what it is now. TL:DR it is nothing like the Kickstarter pitched it would be, which might be just fine, but it isn't what I backed.

One of the first tags you will see for Stonehearth says city builder and when you see that tag do you think of something like Gnomoria or Towns? Probably not. Those are more like town or village builders with some micromanagement and customization of each individual villager, which is great because you you start with maybe half a dozen and build up from there, but even if you end up with 20 villagers (which is a lot for this game) would you say that is a city? You might argue that I'm just talking semantics and being trivial, but let me quote what the Stonehearth Kickstarter summarized the game to be, A sandbox strategy game with town building
recommended: and epic battles!" It certainly does not have town building and crafting at the moment
hoursPlayed: but a strategy game it is not.\n\nAt the moment the game is very much like Gnomoria

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I bought this game as a Christmas Present for myself.  I saw the trailer and thought it looked amazing, so so I picked it up.  I'm glad I did.

As of now, Jan 21st 2016, Stonehearth is in an alpha state.  This means that features are not yet implemetned and the game is bare bones.  That said, it manages to have all the implemented features work well.  There is plenty of annoying things that happen, but the core gameplay is solid.  The bugs and glitches were relatively minor and did not destroy my experience.

The developers for this game seem amazing, and they have weekly blog posts detailing the new content they developed.  They are in touch with the community and support the game, as opposed to many early access developers.  This is a great thing.

The art style of the game is fantastic, and the music is delightful.  The theme that plays when you turn on the game is great.

This is the lightweight version of Dwarf Fortress that I have been waiting for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Backed this game a while ago, great concept, and the Dev team is really doing some work to pull it all together.

I do recomend this game. Its unusually addicting. I try not to play it very often because i want to experience more of the game all at once. Remember it is still very heavily under construction, so buying the game means expect bugs and what not, and please add constructive feedback. This game is backed by an excelent group of Devs.

Great graphics for the style of game, music is addicting to say the least if not a bit repetitive right now. Gameplay although lacking many of the features they want to put in, even in its current state its amazingly fun.
Similar to Timber and Stone but a little less hardcore in the mechanics (another game i recomend you check out). Free build cities block by block. Assign jobs to your people (Carpenters, Stonemasons, Chefs, Soldiers, and many more). Keep them fed happy and protected from an assortment of baddies.

The only con i can see is the price. For the state of the game $25 is a little iffy. Certainly worth maybe $15 if you can catch a sale, and as long as the Devs stay on point it will be worth the $25 or even more.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stonehearth is a very cute, easy-going city builder/sandbox with some combat, though that is a little broken at the moment, as some of the enemies don't even fight your hearthlings properly, and larger battles tend to hurt performance a bit.

You gather resources (mining, lumberjacking, gathering, hunting, farming etc.)  build your city however you want, you can use prefab buildings or create your very own designs.

Stonehearth has a job & crafting system, where you can give each hearthling a role, such as the carpenter or blacksmith, footman or worker. Each hearthling will gain experiance in their given field, which unlocks skills or perks that improve their job performance, unlocking more recipes and such.

The dev's are very active, they stream 2-3 times a week and almost always post updates on their website each tuesday, and update their game on a regular basis.

While it IS an alpha, there is already a lot of content, and more is always being added. Defs worth checking out the roadmap on their website, and talking to the community, which is super-friendly.

Multiplayer is part of stonehearths future - I know many will be wondering this! I believe it will be coop and pvp, so you can build your city with your friends, or build seperate and raid their stockpiles >:D
